comments.commentBody: Helena, your stateent that " IQ all but disappear when children of diverse race but similar social and economic backgrounds are compared" is meaningless, as socail and economic background correlate strongl with IQ, meaning that these are not random samples. You would have to refer to twin studies for a meaningful result.

Neither are the journalistic standards of the full range of "mainstream" media which rapidly picked up the "story" and ran with it. At this point, Rolling Stone's ethics hardly matter; the whole industry needs to examine itself.

There is no excuse to the presumption of guilt that was exhibited by the press and public, similar to the Duke Lacross case. Any real analysis of the statistics suggest a quite high incidence of false accusations of rape. I know of 2 cases personally, one especially sad where the children were taken away from their father for several years during which time (and without proof, without criminal complaint) he was not allowed contact until it became clear that she was abusing the kids. One kid never really recovered, one did.

We also now have the terrible "affirmative consent" laws, which assume several things:
1) Woman are just helpless, weak beings
2) Any act where a male wants sex is presumed to be an assault, even of long time partners.
3) Any persuasion at all towards sex is equivalent to assault.

Thanks for writing Lucy. There can't be many experiences more traumatic than rape, and even more so, gang rape, but I found out unexpectedly that being accused of doing something I didn't do (not rape) was very distressing, too.

As a former journalist and a domestic violence and rape survivor (who was not believed), I am dismayed by this turn of events on every level. Women like me, and our supporters, have worked tirelessly to have our voices heard so that real change can happen in the law and in our culture. By reading the comments here, I can see the setback happening in real time. There is no excuse for shoddy journalism, and the ramifications are potentially disastrous, all the way around.

Agreed.  Totally shirked his responsibility as a a journalist and editor.  Are there no standards to journalistic practice at the Rolling Stone today?  Or are they so desperate to sell their magazine that they're willing to cut corners to publish an attention-grabbing headline?

I don't expect magazines like Rolling Stone to have the highest journalistic ethics, but what gives with the so-called legitimate press, this paper included, who took this story at face value and ran with it?  Any editor should be able to tell you, "Two sources.  Always."
I think Will Dana should tender his resignation on Monday. The man is a disgrace to journalism. Rolling Stone should stick to interviewing old rock stars and leave real reporting to professionals.

Although I did not read the Rolling Stone article, my understanding is the article did not say her back was lacerated with glass shards from the broken table. It merely says the table broke.

And then everybody else — people like yourself — wrongly assumed that meant her back had to be lacerated. You then went a step further and, well, concluded her core rape allegation was false based on what is really your own creative imagination that bears no truth to what the alleged victim even said, or what was written in the Rolling Stone article.

From the beginning, this story did not add up. I cannot imagine even the most arrogant, misogynist, frat animal sexually assaulting a young woman after she crashed through a glass table. And I cannot imagine suffering multiple lacerations from broken glass and not seeking medical care. While it is conceivable that no one would think to document her injuries with photographs, it is also hard to believe.

Was this a plot to discredit a fraternity? Was this retribution for a prior rape? Was this an exaggerated version of what actually happened? We will probably never know the truth. But what is clear is that victims of rape who hope to achieve justice in court or elsewhere must act quickly to gather evidence.

Your comment would be hilarious if it weren't so true. Read some of the comments here - the fact that innocent people were slandered means nothing - there is only regret that the railroading job didn't go as planned.

Well, law enforcement is investigating but the end result should be as widely disseminated as the original RS "article." I look forward to reading the report with names including "jackie" published. If her accusations are false as they'll likely prove to be, I hope UVA expels her for violating the UVA honor code since she is clearly a liar. I further hope every UVA male lifeguard that worked with "jackie" sues her for defamation That is all.

French Laundry and Per Se do not have menus from which guests choose their courses. It is prix fix and the menu is set in advance. Vegetarian options are available as well. So if you go to one of these places, you get what the chef is serving ...a whole other thing for some foodies to complain about. This model will only work for a very few high end restaurants that are in such high demand that they an get away with it.

Many, many good comments, with which I wholeheartedly agree. However, amidst all the outrage over the pomposity, extortion, pretension, etc., is the utter lack of any spontaneity in paying for everything in advance. What if you're in the mood for something lighter, or more spicy, months later? Or if there was a special on some main course because of unexpected availability from the provider? Or what if the pre-paid course's ingredients, months after the fact, turned out not to be available that evening?

I must be missing something. Surely, if I wanted to switch a course to something more expensive when I saw it on the menu, I wouldn't be forced to eat exactly what I paid for? Help me out here.

"Here we are not afraid to follow the truth wherever it may lead, nor to tolerate any error so long as reason is left free to combat it." Thomas Jefferson (founder, for those who might not know, of THE University of Virginia).

No one yet knows the truth. "Jackie" could be 100% right on what happened and too traumatized to remember correctly the details. Or she could have been victimized somehow and created a story that is not entirely true. Or she could have been fantasizing everything. No one yet knows.
There was no rape here. Jackie's story was a lie. That IS the story.
Um, wait. Jackie wasn't raped. She falsely accused innocent people of raping her. She wasn't victimized by anyone, but she and Rolling Stone together have done enormous damage to innocent people.
If you think that's bad, wait 'til it comes out that "Jackie" does not exist.
Washington Post has done an independent investigation that puts the RS piece in question, if you followed the links in this article.

Suddenly, the public statements and claims of a fraternity organization are more credible than those of a victim of sexual assault and rape? The frat claims there wasn't a party that night and none of the bros were lifeguards anyways...so the victim must be lying!

Nope, no patriarchy to see here folks, move along now.

HG, IQ testing has long been known to be highly repeatable and also predictive of academic and financial success, as well as other factors. And no one has been able to devise a "culturally neutral" IQ test that eliminates the gap. Finally, IQ is *known* to be sensitive to environment. However, twin studies find a high degree of heritability, particularly in adults.
Good grief. It isn't on the fraternity to disprove the claims, it's on the accused to prove their claims. That's how justice is supposed to work.

No. In our system of justice, the accused do not have to prove their innocence. And it appears that here, the facts are not even in question. The accuser lied, Rolling Stone magazine accepted and published these lies without even a pretense of due diligence, and innocent people were libeled and seriously harmed. No rape, but a lot of damage done to those falsely accused.

There is absolutely not a single (or "the" as you term it) issue here. There are at least four. One is, as you say, UVA's system for adjudicating the punishments for campus rape and sexual assault. The second is that this accusation in whole or part might not be true. So reputations--personal, social, academic-- have been harmed. The third is that inaccurate or false allegations may make it harder for true accusations to be believed. And the fourth is that the RS standards for journalism and "fact-checking" are sadly lacking and this lack has caused harm.

So whether it is "with or without Jackie" does matter.

The government is not afraid of "more ME unrest" (truly preposterous) or danger to.Americans, but, rightly, "unrest" from its citizens in whose name it tortured. Perhaps an enraged citizenry can drag the war criminals to trial at the Hague.

Americans have no memory, and the USA has no past.

So U.S. killing, torture, toppling of regimes, ruining of economies, reckless pollution, stealing, and ruthless exploitation of populations everywhere goes on and on and on.

The only people who can stop American crimes are the citizens of the USA, and the personalities who rule them do everything under the sun to fill their minds with lies.

You should read the article in the ?Washington Post linked from this article.  The student's friends and peer counselors now have severe out about what occurred.  Her roommate says that the woman did have a huge change in personality around the time the rape was to have occurred but that she (the roommate) is not certain what is truth or fiction in the details.  Another woman--the student peer counselor--introduced Jackie to the RS author who was ding the story on campus sexual assaults.  Whether Jackie felt pressured to talk by her fellow student or the author or both it does appear that not all she said stands scrutiny.  Perhaps she had not told her friends an entirely accurate story and did not know how to stop although she tried, without success, to withdraw her story after having been interviewed several times.   Perhaps we will never know but it appears doubt has been raised not based solely on frat statements.

Couldn't agree more.

Massive damage has been caused.

Though I would disagree that the supposed victim made it up. She is probably just confused, traumatized or perhaps even mentally unstable. In any case she deserves at least some compassion. It does not seem she was trying to cause harm. She was actually preyed upon by the journalist.

The real guilty parties are the journalist and RS - both selfish in the extreme and have caused enormous harm. Both should be made to pay dearly - on the order of spending the next few decades working to repay The University, the fraternity and women's rights groups.

Nobody is suggesting that exposure of this flawed piece of journalism is "enough to bury the issue of sexual assault." Merely that the story of a specific and horrific sexual assault cannot at this point be credited as true.

I don't understand why it is so important to uphold the idea that there is virtually never a false rape allegation. False reports of crimes generally are rare, but they do happen. It doesn't discredit rape victims to say that, once in a while, people make things up. Some people have neuroses or worse that drive them to seek attention through telling people their fantasies. It happens. Saying so does not equate to "patriarchy" or "rape culture." It is merely common sense, based on the life we all live in the world. Liars exist. Why dispute that? We've all dealt with liars. There are no categories of behavior that liars won't lie about. Why does anyone think lying about rape is a line a liar wouldn't cross?

Another possibility is that she was raped, but she embellished the surrounding events. It's important to know this because her story implicates six men in a felony. Perhaps there is one felon -- and five falsely accused. Now that the police are involved, perhaps we can learn what really happened, determining if Jackie is indeed a victim and if any of six accused young men were falsely accused in a national magazine.

Maybe "Drew" lied about working at the pool with her? As in he dressed up like like a lifeguard and came to "work" everyday until he gained her trust?

We're now exiting the ridiculous and entering the downright goofy.

sorry, I'm not buying. Fraternal power is at work: there was no "organized function" and no phi kappa psi who worked at a pool? That is supposed to be enough to bury the issue of sexual assault. I can think of an argument against without getting up from the couch. After reading the article "Drew" didn't have much character. Maybe he lied. Trauma does weird things to recollection.

There is a whole lot at stake here. On the one hand one little woman's life and on the other? the viability of Fraternities, the reputation of the University of Virginia? We've been reading about police reports that disappear when somebody is an athlete for heaven's sake. This is what happens when somebody "disrespects" the institution - whatever it is as long as it's male.

Those people who wonder why someone didn't report the offenses at Notre Dame - now do you see how these things usually shake out?

As far as the male Catholic justices are concerned, they may harken to a source older than the Constitution:
Genesis 3:16 - Unto the woman he said, I will greatly multiply thy sorrow and thy conception; in sorrow thou shalt bring forth children; and thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee.

Written, of course, by a misogynistic male.

... so much for objectivity.

Voss reply: "It would be nice for the five male, Catholic justices that sit in the majority to understand that women alone are tasked with perpetuating the human race." Let's note the Catholic church has not come out and urged that this legislation be passed. Always silent on women's real needs not to mention over population (more suffering souls to save).

Rome really worships misery and suffering (just to be Christ like in their minds) to allow them to give out alms and empty words primarily to feel good about themselves. Sick. And I would prefer bad mental health not be forced on me.

It would be nice for the five male, Catholic justices that sit in the majority to understand that women alone are tasked with perpetuating the human race. Unless one or more of these justices has actually given birth himself, how can they possibly determine that women should be treated equally in the work place ? If UPS , or any business, fails to accommodate what nature demands, than a rational decision must be made by the five Catholic conservatives that control the Supreme Court. Each of these justices must recognize the very obvious fact that they would not exist were it not for their mothers. The equation seems simple enough. No business would be in business without the requisite number of people to operate the business. Women are the most integral part of that equation and must be recognized as such. The failure of the Court to accept women as fully equal citizens would be to declare the fourteenth amendment null and void for some 50% of our entire population.
There is no corroborating evidence.

There are discrepancies that have emerged which is common to these kinds of stories. Victims memories aren't completely reliable, neither are perpetrators. There is still enough corroborating evidence to indicate that Jackie was raped at a UVA fraternity that weekend. If it followed a dinner at a restaurant I hope then the police investigation will find a record of it. More facts need to emerge, we still don't have a clear picture and need a thorough investigation. The vitriole expressed by many of the commentors against RS is also a rush to judgment. My experience at UVA influences me to believe Jackie because I know that UVA undergraduate behavior can be vile and cruel after a certain hour on the weekends.
Is it even relevant whether he would have been more productive? Is the measure of a man's worth solely what (and apparently how much) he can produce?  What tripe.
